Engineering Example: Heat flow in an insulated metal plate

Introduction 

Thermal insulation is important in many domestic (e.g. central heating) and industrial (e.g cooling and heating) situations. Although many real situations involve heat flow in more than one dimension, we consider only a one dimensional case here. The flow of heat is determined by temperature and thermal conductivity. It is possible to model the amount of heat \(Q\) (\(\textrm{J}\)) crossing point \(x\) in one dimension (the heat flow in the \(x\) direction) from temperature \(T_2\) \((\textrm{K})\) to temperature \(T_1\) \((\textrm{K})\) (in which \(T_2>T_1\)) in time \(t\) (\(\textrm{s}\)) by

\(\qquad\dfrac{Q}{t}=\lambda A\left(\dfrac{T_2-T_1}{x}\right),\)

where \(\lambda\) is the thermal conductivity in \(\textrm{Wm}^{-1}\textrm{K}\).

Problem in words

Suppose that the upper and lower sides of a metal plate connecting two containers are insulated and one end is maintained at a temperature \(T_2\) \((\textrm{K})\) (see the figure below)

The plate is assumed to be infinite in the direction perpendicular to the sheet of paper.


  1. Find a formula for \(T\).
  2. If \(\lambda =205\) \((\textrm{Wm}^{-1}\textrm{K})\), \(T_1 = 300\) \((\textrm{K})\), \(A=0.004\) \((\textrm{m}^2)\), \(x=0.5\) \((\textrm{m})\), calculate the value of \(T_2\) required to achieve a heat flow of \(100\) \((\textrm{Js}^{-1})\).

Mathematical statement of the problem

  1. Given \(\dfrac{Q}{t}=\lambda A\left(\dfrac{T_2-T_1}{x}\right)\) express \(T_2\) as the subject of the formula.
  2. In the formula found in part (a) substitute \(\lambda =205,\ T_1 =300,\ A=0.004\), \(x=0.5\) and \(\dfrac{Q}{t}=100\) to find \(T_2\).

Mathematical analysis

  1. \(\dfrac{Q}{t}=\lambda A\left(\dfrac{T_2-T_1}{x}\right)\)

    Divide both sides by \(\lambda A\)

    \(\qquad\dfrac{Q}{t \lambda A}=\dfrac{T_2-T_1}{x}\)

    Multiply both sides by \(x\)

    \(\qquad\dfrac{Qx}{t \lambda A}=T_2-T_1\)

    \(\qquad\dfrac{Qx}{t \lambda A}+T_1=T_2\)

    which is equivalent to

    \(\qquad T_2=\dfrac{Qx}{t \lambda A}+T_1\)

  2. Substitute \(\quad \lambda =205,\ T_1 =300,\ A=0.004 ,\ x=0.5\) and \(\dfrac{Q}{t}=100\) to find \(T_2\): \[T_2=\dfrac{100\times 0.5}{205\times 0.004}+300 \approx 60.9 +300=360.9\] So the temperature in container 2 is \(361\) \((\textrm{K})\) to 3 sig.fig.

Interpretation

The formula \(\ T_2=\dfrac{Qx}{t \lambda A}+T_1\) can be used to find a value for \(T_2\) that would achieve any desired heat flow. In the example given \(T_2\) would need to be about \(361\) \((\textrm{K})\) \((\approx 78^\circ\textrm{C})\) to produce a heat flow of \(100\) \((\textrm{Js}^{-1})\).
